You also believe that votes are usually counted fairly in your country, and you think opposition candidates are rarely prevented from running in elections. While you value democratic governance, you believe it would be bad to have a system governed by religious law without elections or political parties. You place importance on being able to vote in local elections and view ensuring strong defense forces as an essential part of national governance.

You do not consider yourself close to your continent, region, or district, and you are not particularly interested in politics, although you are occasionally involved in political discussions with friends. You don't mind discussing political matters but prefer to keep a distance from intense political debates. Your political views are also reflected in your stance on international issues. You are generally in favor of international organizations such as the United Nations and NATO but have little confidence in the World Bank, major companies, or environmental organizations. While you do believe in the importance of international cooperation, you lean towards prioritizing effectiveness over democracy in these organizations.

You believe in the right to privacy and personal freedom, feeling that people should have the freedom to choose their actions without excessive government intervention. For example, you do not believe that the government should have the right to video-surveil people in public areas, although you are open to other forms of security. You also value the importance of providing long-term care for parents, even though you do not consider it an obligation of society. As for your views on immigration, you believe the government should allow people to come if there are jobs available, though you also feel that immigration can sometimes lead to social conflict and terrorism risks. You support the idea that immigration strengthens cultural diversity but believe it should be regulated to maintain job vacancies for citizens.

Regarding social issues, you are supportive of equal opportunities for women in public office and agree that a man beating his wife is never justified. You also oppose political violence, believing it is almost never justified. However, you feel that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents, reflecting a traditional sense of responsibility within families. You do not mind having unmarried couples, homosexuals, heavy drinkers, or people with AIDS as neighbors. You believe that homosexual couples are just as capable of being good parents as other couples.

In terms of personal beliefs and behaviors, you place a high value on individual responsibility. You feel that people should take more responsibility for their own well-being and that income equality should not be a top priority of democracy. You believe that people working hard will lead to a better life and that competition can be beneficial, although you are not overly concerned with its potential harms. You feel that science and technology will bring more opportunities for the next generation, but you remain skeptical about some of the changes they bring to society, including their impact on our sense of right and wrong.

You are not very close to global events or to the world as a whole, and you prefer to maintain a balance between global awareness and personal responsibility. You do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, but you feel there should be limits to immigration based on available jobs. You are also somewhat concerned about the potential impact of immigration on the economy and social structure but remain open-minded about its positive contributions. You place your personal and family life as a priority and have a positive outlook on your health and future.

Finally, while you are not a member of any large organizations, you are actively involved in professional and charitable activities. You believe that human rights are important and that organizations like Amnesty International contribute to protecting these rights. You have donated to causes before and are not afraid to take action, whether by signing petitions or participating in boycotts or strikes when necessary.
58879:
You were born in 1996 in country 496, and today, at the age of 24, you lead a relatively stable and secure life. You live with your mother and your child in a household of three people. You describe yourself as being of lower middle-class background, belonging to the fourth-lowest income group in your country. Despite this, you feel you have a great deal of control over your life and are very satisfied with your current situation, rating your overall happiness a solid 10 out of 10. In fact, you would even describe your health as good, and you’ve never had to go without food, medicine, or medical treatment in the past year.

Your father was born in country 496 and completed upper secondary education, while your mother’s background is the same, with both of your parents being citizens of this country. You have a Bachelor's degree or equivalent, and you are employed full-time, working 30 or more hours a week. You are part of the professional and technical group, working in a job such as a teacher, nurse, or engineer. Despite being involved in your career, you don't place much importance on leisure time and find work to be a duty toward society. 

While you feel a strong connection to your country and region, your views on religion are complex. Although you don't belong to any religious denomination and identify as not a religious person, you still consider religion to be somewhat important in your life, though you don't believe in God or hell. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than strictly following religious norms and ceremonies. This stance, along with your lack of confidence in the churches, indicates a nuanced approach to faith and spirituality.

Regarding your political beliefs, you hold moderately left-leaning views, placing yourself at position 3 on the left-right political scale. While you are not a member of any political party, you are quite interested in politics and occasionally discuss political matters with friends. However, you have mixed feelings about how democracy functions in your country, believing that while there is some respect for individual human rights, your country’s elections are not always fair. You rate your country's level of democracy highly at 9 out of 10, but you’re dissatisfied with the political system and lack confidence in the press, political parties, and parliament. You have a deep distrust of the government and any form of state surveillance, believing that there is a very high risk of corruption among state authorities, with your country ranking a solid 10 out of 10 for corruption in your eyes. You feel strongly that corruption affects many local authorities and business executives. 

You are also critical of the electoral system in your country, feeling that votes are not always counted fairly and that voters are often bribed. Despite these concerns, you believe the importance of having honest elections cannot be overstated. Your stance on political violence is clear: you believe it is never justified. When it comes to handling societal issues, you lean toward having experts, not government officials, making decisions, and you place a high value on national defense, considering it the most important goal for your country over the next decade.

Your views on family and gender roles align with traditional values. Family is paramount to you, and you feel that one of your main life goals has been to make your parents proud. You believe that having children is a societal duty, and you agree that adult children should provide long-term care for their parents. You are very proud of your country's nationality but also recognize the importance of good manners, independence, and unselfishness as values to teach children. You consider the ability to save money, be responsible, and avoid selfishness to be essential qualities for the younger generation.

When it comes to relationships, you are fairly conservative. You don't mind unmarried couples living together as neighbors, but you strongly oppose casual sex, believing it is never justified. Similarly, you believe that sex before marriage is not acceptable. However, you do not mind having people of different religions or sexual orientations as neighbors, though you are uncomfortable with people having AIDS or being heavy drinkers. Your views on marriage and family dynamics are traditional, as you feel that a woman earning more money than her husband would almost certainly cause problems, and you also believe that working mothers can negatively affect their children.

Your thoughts on social issues are equally complex. You have no confidence in environmental organizations but are actively involved in women's organizations, supporting their causes. You believe that the World Bank, the United Nations, and the World Health Organization play important roles in global governance. You also support having stricter immigration controls, particularly in relation to foreign workers and asylum seekers. You are worried about the impact of terrorism, civil war, and other violent political events, and although you worry about job security and the risks of social conflict due to immigration, you do not believe immigrants increase crime rates.

You are not a member of any humanitarian, charitable, or professional organizations, but you have been involved in consumer and women's groups, showing that you value participation in social causes. You have even donated to campaigns and are open to taking action on political issues, such as signing electronic petitions or participating in a boycott.

Your views on society’s moral compass are firm. You believe that violence against others is never justified, including wife-beating, child abuse, and suicide. Similarly, you feel strongly that euthanasia, prostitution, and terrorism are never acceptable. When it comes to competition, you lean slightly toward seeing it as a good thing, although you are not overly enthusiastic about it. You also believe that science and technology have a place in making lives healthier and more comfortable, but you worry that our society is too dependent on science and not enough on faith, a sentiment you hold to a very high degree.

In terms of practical matters, you avoid carrying much cash and have taken steps to ensure your safety by avoiding going out at night. You believe that robberies do occur somewhat frequently in your neighborhood, though you do not feel unsafe in your home, and your neighborhood is free from many other forms of crime, including drugs, alcohol consumption, and sexual harassment. Your neighborhood also does not experience much racial tension, and you feel it is very unlikely for people in your area to be involved in corruption or bribery.

You maintain a high level of trust in your family, and although friends are not particularly important to you, you do occasionally talk politics with them. You rarely seek political information from friends or colleagues, relying more on the internet, mobile phones, and TV news. You prefer daily updates from these sources, though you are not highly confident in their accuracy. Additionally, you value information from daily newspapers, though you tend to avoid relying on them more than once a month.

Though you are not religious, you believe in the importance of being respectful to others and that family values and strong moral principles should be taught to children. You also place great importance on societal goals like fighting rising prices and maintaining a strong defense. You trust banks and major companies but have little confidence in the press, political parties, or labor unions. You do not mind living next to immigrants or foreign workers, but you believe that governments should prioritize people from your own country when jobs are scarce. 

Despite your many concerns about politics, religion, and society, you feel strongly about protecting individual freedoms and rights, though you would choose security over freedom if faced with a choice. You would fight for your country in times of war and take part in peaceful demonstrations if necessary. You also remain critical of the idea that political violence or a military dictatorship could ever be justified or beneficial for your country.

Ultimately, you strike a balance between traditional values, personal independence, and a nuanced approach to both religion and politics. You strive for a better future for your family and country, driven by principles of hard work, respect, and social stability.
54988:
You were born in 1938 in country 484 and are now 80 years old. You live in your country regularly, with a household consisting of two people, including yourself. Your family is important to you, and you have two children. You are proud of your nationality and feel very close to both your country and your county, region, or district. Family and friends are central to your life, and you consider good manners, responsibility, imagination, and unselfishness important qualities for children to learn.

Religion plays a significant role in your life. You belong to the Protestant denomination and attend religious services once a week. You consider yourself a religious person and believe that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others and to make sense of life in this world, rather than focusing on the afterlife. You do not believe in hell. Your views on religion are clear: you strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science, and you feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections.

Regarding your political views, you place yourself in the center of the left-right scale. Although you are not a member of any political party, you do have opinions on the functioning of your country’s political system. You are quite satisfied with how the political system operates these days (level 8/10), and you feel very close to your country and the world. You consider good governance, strong defense forces, and economic growth to be top priorities for the nation. You strongly agree that civil rights and the army taking over when the government is incompetent are essential characteristics of democracy, as well as the need for honest elections and people obeying their rulers.

You believe the government should not have the right to monitor emails or conduct surveillance in public spaces. While you trust your government quite a lot, you are skeptical about the integrity of its various branches, as you believe that corruption is rampant within state and local authorities. You also think that election officials are fair only sometimes, and that bribery and corruption occur frequently in your country, especially in relation to local authorities and civil service providers. You are particularly wary of the influence of wealth in politics, believing that the rich often buy elections and bribe officials.

In terms of society, you think that work is a fundamental duty towards society, and it plays an important role in your life. You would consider freedom more important than equality if you had to choose between the two. You also believe that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time, and you feel it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You hold strong opinions about various aspects of social behavior: for instance, you believe that people who don’t work are lazy, and you strongly disagree with the idea that casual sex, stealing, or violence against others can ever be justified. Similarly, you oppose prostitution, euthanasia, and terrorism.

Your thoughts on immigration reflect a belief that while immigration strengthens cultural diversity and provides important job opportunities, it can also lead to social conflict and increased risks of terrorism. You agree that the government should allow people to come as long as jobs are available, but you prefer that employers give priority to people from your country over immigrants when jobs are scarce. Additionally, you feel that immigration should provide asylum to political refugees. You are, however, not in favor of having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, nor do you want people of a different religion or homosexuals as neighbors. 

Regarding global institutions, you have significant confidence in organizations like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the United Nations, the World Bank, and the International Criminal Court. You also trust major companies, banks, labor unions, and environmental organizations, although you are not a member of any of these groups. While you believe that international organizations should prioritize democracy over effectiveness, you also think that countries should focus on strong defense, maintaining order, and managing inflation. You also strongly agree that science and technology make our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable, although you also recognize some negative consequences, such as the breakdown of moral boundaries.

On the personal front, you are retired and live comfortably with your spouse, who is or was a housewife. Your financial situation is stable, and you are very satisfied with your household's financial situation (level 9/10). You do not have much concern about losing your job, as you have already retired, but you are worried about providing a good education for your children. Despite this, you do not feel very secure these days, as crime rates are higher in your neighborhood. You have experienced crime personally, and robberies occur quite frequently in your area. However, you are not worried much about unemployment and do not often carry a weapon for security reasons.

You trust people you meet for the first time somewhat, but you have complete trust in your family. You have mixed feelings about competition, considering it both beneficial and harmful, but slightly favoring it as good. Your confidence in the media is moderate, and you regularly obtain information from newspapers, TV news, radio, and friends. You avoid obtaining information from the Internet or social media, as you do not trust those sources. You are neutral on the role of science in daily life, believing it to be neither important nor unimportant.

You place a high value on a strong sense of responsibility and personal integrity, and you believe that people should prioritize work and be unselfish. While you are concerned about the lack of respect for human rights and the state of democracy in your country, you remain hopeful for the future and feel that both hard work and luck contribute to success. You also believe that a high level of economic growth should be the top priority for your country in the next ten years, followed by fighting rising prices. You would never join a boycott, strike, or electronic petition, as you prefer to handle matters through more traditional channels.

You are quite conservative in your views on family, and you believe that children should be taught obedience and responsibility. You strongly oppose actions like physical violence against children, spouses, or women, and you believe that having children is a duty towards society. You would not want to have unmarried couples, people with AIDS, heavy drinkers, or people who engage in immoral behavior as neighbors.

Your beliefs about society and politics reflect a complex balance between tradition, a strong sense of responsibility, and a deep commitment to democratic values, even as you are skeptical about the effectiveness of political structures and the integrity of your government. Despite concerns about corruption and the erosion of civil rights, you remain committed to the idea of a democratic system that protects human dignity and promotes social stability.
28894:
You were born in 1952, in country 826, and you are now 69 years old. You feel a deep sense of pride in your nationality and consider your country to be completely democratic, rating it a perfect 10 out of 10 on the scale of democracy. You are also very close to your country and its values. You believe that your standard of living today is better than your parents' when they were about your age. Family is very important in your life, and you live regularly with one other person in your household. You are retired and live on a pension, and you have a strong confidence in your country's civil service, government, and political system. You strongly agree that honest elections are crucial, and you always vote in local elections.

You place a great deal of confidence in institutions like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the World Health Organization, and the International Criminal Court. You trust your family completely, and you are confident in banks, major companies, the armed forces, and the press. You also have a great deal of confidence in the civil service, parliament, and TV news. When it comes to your financial situation, you are very satisfied, rating it a 9 out of 10. You belong to the eighth-highest income group in your country, and your family saved money during the past year.

Your religious beliefs play a role in your life, although not a dominant one. You are a Protestant and you consider yourself a religious person, but you don’t attend religious services often—if at all. Religion is not very important in your day-to-day life, and you don’t mind having people of different religions or homosexuals as neighbors. You believe in God, but you strongly disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science.

Politically, you consider yourself moderately right-leaning, rating yourself a 7 on the left-right scale. You occasionally discuss politics with friends and feel quite strongly about political matters. You believe political violence is never justified, and you think terrorism as a means of political action is absolutely unjustifiable. You believe in democracy, supporting the notion that a democratic system with political parties and elections is essential. You strongly feel that a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections would be very bad. You strongly agree that the army should not take over when the government is incompetent, and you believe that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. 

When it comes to economic and political systems, you believe in both freedom and equality, though you prioritize freedom when forced to choose between the two. You moderately support a system that ensures more equal incomes, but you feel that individuals should also have some personal responsibility. You would say that your country’s political system is working well, and you believe that voters are treated fairly in elections. You don’t mind if the government places restrictions on the number of immigrants coming into the country, though you also agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You do not believe that immigration increases the crime rate or leads to social conflict, but you think immigrants have a quite bad impact on the development of your country. 

Regarding your views on work, you find it not very important in your life, but you do believe that hard work generally brings a better life, even if it is only a part of the equation. You are moderately in favor of government taking more responsibility to provide for people, with limited emphasis on individual responsibility. You might join a boycott or sign an electronic petition, but have not yet done so. You agree with the idea that economic growth should be prioritized in the next decade, although you feel that progress toward a society where ideas count more than money is the second most important goal.

On the topic of social issues, you strongly agree that homosexual couples are just as good parents as other couples, and you believe that having casual sex is almost always justified. You are also an advocate for sexual freedom, believing that sex before marriage is always justified and that prostitution is always justified. However, you also believe that children should learn important qualities such as good manners, a sense of responsibility, tolerance, respect for others, thrift, and independence. You don’t believe in the duty of children to provide long-term care for their parents, nor do you believe in the duty of society to have children. You consider imagination and determination unimportant qualities for children to learn, but you think unselfishness is important.

In your neighborhood, you feel secure and safe. There is no crime such as robberies, alcohol consumption in the streets, or drug sales. You’ve never gone without enough food or medical treatment, and you are not worried about a civil war or terrorist attacks. In your opinion, people rarely have to pay bribes or do favors for local officials, and you do not experience police or military interference in your private life. You don’t mind having people with HIV or homosexuals as neighbors, and you do not believe in hell. You strongly disagree with any form of physical punishment for children, and you believe violence against others is never justified.

In terms of global perspectives, you have somewhat low confidence in the United Nations and the European Union, but you have more trust in organizations like the World Bank, the World Trade Organization, and environmental groups. You strongly disagree with the idea that religion should play a dominant role in shaping society’s laws, especially in a democracy. You would not want experts to make decisions for the country, as you believe government should still hold authority in such matters. You also trust the police and military but don’t believe the army should rule when the government fails.

Your view on the economy is somewhat nuanced: you somewhat support private ownership of business and industry, with some support for government ownership, but you feel that competition is largely beneficial, even with minimal concerns about its harms. You moderately believe that incomes should be more equal but still believe in the importance of individual incentives. You think the state's role should be to maintain order in the nation, but you do not feel it’s necessary for governments to prioritize being democratic over being effective in international organizations.

Lastly, your state of health is poor, and you moderately believe that euthanasia is justified in certain cases. You strongly agree that science and technology have greatly improved the quality of life, although you feel we depend too much on science and not enough on faith. You do not feel close to the world at large and have no strong connections to your region, district, or continent. You consider leisure time very important in your life, and you don’t mind less emphasis being placed on work. You enjoy discussing politics, but you would never attend a demonstration or join a strike, and you would never encourage others to take political action.
852:
You were born in 1944 in Country 724. As an immigrant to this country, you feel fairly proud of your nationality, but you also hold mixed views on certain aspects of this society. Religion holds no significant place in your life, and you believe that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow strict norms or ceremonies. Despite this, you consider yourself a religious person, and you belong to the Roman Catholic denomination. You rarely attend religious services and do not believe in hell.

Your family plays a central role in your life, and you consider them to be very important. You're especially driven to make your parents proud, which has been one of your main goals in life. Family values are important to you, and you strongly agree that children should learn qualities like tolerance, respect, responsibility, and determination. However, you don't consider imagination, independence, or thrift as essential qualities for children to learn. You do not believe that parents should beat their children, nor do you believe that children should provide long-term care for their parents.

You are a female who is now retired and living in a household that includes one other person. Your family has never gone without enough food or needed medical treatment in the past 12 months, and you have not felt unsafe from crime in your home recently. Your family’s financial situation is moderately satisfactory, though you describe yourself as belonging to the lower-middle class and the fourth-lowest income group in the country. Your current state of health is good, and you feel secure in your day-to-day life, with no worries about losing your job.

Politics is not something you pay much attention to, although you are actively involved in a political party. You do not discuss political matters with your friends, nor would you ever join a boycott or a strike. However, you do agree that the country should have a democratic political system, even if you have no confidence in the government or parliament. You consider political violence never justified, and you strongly disagree with any form of violence, including terrorism and domestic violence. You do not believe that political violence, suicide, or stealing property is ever justified. Your trust in authorities is minimal, as you have no confidence in political parties, the press, the government, or major institutions like the IMF, World Bank, and the United Nations.

Despite your skepticism toward government and international organizations, you believe that democracy should protect civil rights, provide equal opportunities, and ensure that people have a say in decisions that affect them. You think that protecting freedom of speech is paramount and that voters should not be threatened with violence or bribed in elections. However, you are not convinced that elections are always fair in your country, as you believe election officials and many authorities are involved in corruption. You feel strongly that honest elections are crucial, and you would not want a system governed by religious law or a leader who bypasses parliament and elections.

You have a moderate belief in the role of government in the economy, supporting limited private ownership and government control of business. You also believe that the government should prioritize democratic values over effectiveness in international organizations. On the issue of equality versus freedom, you would prioritize equality, although you slightly favor individual responsibility over government responsibility. However, you do believe that security is more important than freedom in times of crisis.

Your views on social issues reflect your complex perspective on human rights and relationships. You have no problem with unmarried couples living together as neighbors and do not mind people of different religions or sexual orientations living near you. You also believe that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples. However, you are not entirely in favor of the idea that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, though you feel that immigration can offer people from poor countries a better life. You are somewhat concerned about immigration’s impact on social conflict but are less sure whether it leads to terrorism or fills important job vacancies.

When it comes to societal issues, you feel that personal liberties should be prioritized. You strongly disagree with the idea that a man beating his wife, stealing property, or even forcing people to obey rulers is ever justified. You also oppose the death penalty and hold no confidence in law enforcement or other institutions in your country. In terms of moral stances, you do not believe that people should obey religious authorities when it conflicts with laws, nor do you think women have fewer opportunities in politics or business than men. You also disagree that men make better business executives or political leaders.

Your general perspective on modern society shows some conflicting views on progress and tradition. You believe in science's importance to future generations but feel that too much reliance on science undermines ideas of right and wrong. On the topic of economic issues, you support more equality in incomes but also believe that economic growth is essential. You consider work very important in your life, though you wouldn’t mind a reduced focus on work in society. You are not particularly interested in science or politics, and you do not seek political information online. You also strongly disagree that it is a societal duty to have children, believing that having children should not be a forced obligation.

You value the importance of peaceful demonstrations and have attended them before. At the same time, you have no confidence in environmental organizations or most international institutions, though you do think that progress in science and technology will offer future generations more opportunities. However, you strongly believe that success is more a matter of luck and connections rather than hard work.

Throughout your life, you have been relatively isolated from criminal activity and political conflict, and you have not faced many personal threats or worries about the future. While you feel there are challenges in society, your faith in human potential and the importance of non-violent political action keeps you hopeful for change. You may not be politically active in the traditional sense, but you firmly believe in democracy’s core principles and in the importance of people being able to freely express their views and make decisions about their lives.
36464:
You were born in 1987 in country 360, and you are a 31-year-old woman who considers family an incredibly important part of your life. You live in a household with six members, including yourself, and you reside with your own parent(s). Family bonds are a significant part of your identity, and you cherish friends as well. You are married to a spouse who belongs to the farm worker group, working either as a farm laborer or tractor driver, and your spouse has completed upper secondary education. You have two children, and you place great value on teaching children important qualities like good manners, responsibility, and respect for others.

Your religious beliefs play a central role in your life, as you belong to the Muslim denomination and view religion as essential. You attend religious services only on special holy days and consider yourself a religious person. You strongly believe that the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and you also believe in the existence of hell. However, when science and religion conflict, you believe that religion is always right. Your faith, however, does not prevent you from having some trust in institutions like the World Bank, the World Health Organization, and the European Union, all of which you have a great deal of confidence in. Additionally, you have considerable trust in the press, television, civil service, and international organizations such as NATO and the United Nations. 

Your political views are shaped by your beliefs, though politics is not particularly important in your life. You are not a member of any political party or other formal organizations like humanitarian or charitable groups. You consider yourself moderately left-leaning on the political spectrum, placing your views at position 3 on the left-right scale. You believe that the country’s political system is fairly democratic, with an 8/10 rating for its current functioning, and you have considerable confidence in how elections are conducted, even if you are aware of corruption in the political system. You also have concerns about the extent of corruption at local levels and among state authorities, rating it a solid 8/10.

You tend to avoid discussing political matters with friends and prefer to keep such topics private. Despite not engaging much in politics, you have clear opinions on several issues. You strongly believe in the importance of having a democratic political system, and you feel that one of the country’s most important goals should be ensuring that the people have a say in decisions about their jobs and communities. However, you also believe that there should be a strong leader in charge, one who does not need to be bound by the constraints of parliament and elections. 

Your views on society are influenced by your values. You believe that work is important and that people should fulfill their duties toward society, but you slightly disagree with the idea that work should always come first, even at the expense of leisure time. You see work as a duty, but you also place a significant emphasis on having free time for yourself and your family. This perspective aligns with your belief that leisure time is very important in your life. You also think that equality is more important than freedom when it comes to societal priorities. 

In your view, immigration has both positive and negative effects. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, and offers people from poorer countries better life opportunities. However, you also think that immigration can increase the risk of terrorism and social conflict. You believe that there should be strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work in the country, and you feel that the government should prioritize its own citizens over immigrants when jobs are scarce. At the same time, you support immigration to some extent, as it can offer asylum to political refugees and fill gaps in the job market.

When it comes to moral values, you are firm in your beliefs. You find things like theft, violence, and terrorism to be unjustified, with a neutral stance on their justification. Similarly, you have strong views on family dynamics: you disagree with the idea that men should always have more right to a job than women when jobs are scarce, and you also disagree with the notion that a woman earning more money than her husband is almost always problematic. However, you do not support unmarried couples living together as neighbors, nor do you approve of having homosexual couples or heavy drinkers as neighbors. You also have reservations about practices like prostitution, casual sex, and euthanasia.

Your economic outlook reflects a moderate stance on income distribution. You somewhat believe that there should be greater incentives for individual effort, with some support for income equality. You also moderately believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased, while supporting private ownership to some extent. Despite these views, you feel that your standard of living is better than your parents' at the same age, and you feel relatively satisfied with your financial situation. However, your family has sometimes gone without enough food or medicine in the past year, which highlights the challenges your household faces.

When it comes to security, you feel very safe and have not carried any weapons for protection. Your neighborhood is free of issues like racism, alcohol consumption, drug sales, and robberies. You also believe that the police or military do not interfere with private life in your area, making it a relatively peaceful place to live.

Despite your confidence in various institutions, you hold reservations about certain aspects of society. You believe that competition can sometimes be harmful, though you appreciate its benefits. You also think that some people are more successful due to luck and connections rather than hard work. On the other hand, you do not believe in the idea of depending too much on science, although you do see its importance in certain aspects of life. You also maintain that people who receive state aid for unemployment do not have a necessary role in a democratic system.

Lastly, you are deeply concerned about crime and the potential threat of terrorism. You worry about the possibility of losing your job or being unable to find one, and you are particularly concerned about the potential consequences of a civil war or terrorist attack. Despite these worries, you are committed to your country and would be willing to fight to defend it if necessary.

You are satisfied with your life overall, rating your general happiness at 8/10. While you have a moderate level of concern about certain aspects of society and the world, you still feel that you have a fair amount of control over how your life unfolds. Your strong sense of family, religious faith, and belief in democracy guide your everyday decisions and values.
77237:
You were born in 1970 in country 702, where you still live today. You are a 49-year-old female who considers herself a religious person, belonging to the Protestant denomination. Religion is not a major aspect of your life, but you do believe in God. The basic meaning of religion for you is to make sense of life in this world, rather than focusing on the afterlife. You do not attend religious services frequently, and you do not believe in hell. Your religious views are somewhat aligned with the belief that religion serves a purpose beyond just moral conduct—helping make sense of life’s struggles and offering structure.

Family plays an important role in your life. You are married, and your spouse is from the service sector, having no formal education or only early childhood education. You have three children, and although you consider independence and responsibility important qualities for them to learn, you do not place much importance on qualities like imagination or good manners. You are part of a five-person household, including yourself, and you live with your children, but you do not live with your parents or in-laws. Your father was born in country 702, and your mother, having only early childhood education, has had a profound influence on your upbringing.

You take your responsibilities seriously. Your children are a central focus of your life, and you agree that it is a societal duty to have children. You would never encourage others to take action about political issues and tend to avoid discussing politics with friends. However, you strongly believe in the importance of working hard. You believe that work is a duty towards society, and you consider work very important in your life. Although you are employed part-time (less than 30 hours a week), you hold strong views on the value of hard work, and you believe success is more a matter of luck and connections than just hard work. You somewhat agree with the idea that individual effort should be incentivized, though you also support some income equality. You feel a sense of responsibility for your family’s welfare and take pride in the life you’ve built.

Politically, you are neither a member of any political party nor any political group. You place your political views slightly to the right on the left-right scale. You believe democracy is important, with a democratic political system being something you value deeply. For you, the government should not have the right to monitor e-mails or information exchanged on the Internet, and you hold strong views against state surveillance in public areas. While you agree that votes are counted fairly often in your country’s elections, you have no confidence in major international institutions like the World Bank, the United Nations, or NATO. In fact, you have little faith in these institutions overall, finding them ineffective or corrupt. Despite this, you feel that the basic meaning of democracy lies in individual freedoms, civil rights, and government taxation to ensure equal incomes.

You believe strongly in a number of democratic principles, such as civil rights protecting people from state oppression and the importance of democratic values over effectiveness in international organizations. You would place the need for a strong defense force and a more beautiful environment as key national priorities. When it comes to the rights of women in political office, you think women have equal opportunities to run very often in your country. You disagree with the idea that men make better political leaders or business executives than women. You also feel that immigrants, while potentially contributing to cultural diversity, may not necessarily have a good or bad impact on your country’s development.

Your thoughts on immigration are complex. You believe the government should prohibit people from other countries from coming to work, and you hold that immigrants could increase the risk of terrorism. You also believe that when jobs are scarce, preference should be given to people of your country over immigrants. You do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, but you feel that competition may sometimes be harmful, though you appreciate its benefits. You have mixed views on the impact of immigration on social conflict, job vacancies, and crime.

You find it hard to say whether immigration strengthens or weakens society. You believe that the immigration system should prioritize national citizens, yet you see cultural diversity as a strength. You also hold that the government should make efforts to support unemployed citizens and provide assistance to political refugees, as these are essential characteristics of a functioning democracy. However, your confidence in the ability of international organizations like the United Nations or the World Trade Organization is minimal, and you feel somewhat skeptical of their ability to effectively solve global problems.

On personal and community issues, you value trust and security. You feel quite secure in your life, having never been the victim of a crime in the past year, and there are no concerns about robberies or other criminal activities in your neighborhood. You do not mind having people of different religions or sexual orientations as neighbors, but you do not want to live next door to heavy drinkers, homosexuals, or people involved in prostitution. You believe that racism does not occur in your neighborhood, and that police or military interference with private life does not occur. However, you strongly disapprove of any form of violence, including domestic abuse, and believe that political violence, terrorism, or stealing property is never justified.

Your approach to political violence and social justice is firm: you believe that political violence is never justified, and you oppose any form of aggression or oppression. You also believe that parents should provide long-term care for their elderly family members, a responsibility that should not fall to the state. Furthermore, you are opposed to violence against others, and you would never support any form of terrorism.

You are proud of your country's nationality, and you feel close to your country, even though you do not consider yourself closely connected to the continent or the world. You believe your country is fairly democratic in its governance, but there is still corruption within the civil service and other sectors. Despite this, you have a fair amount of confidence in the civil service, and you hold a strong belief in the importance of human rights, even if you do not always trust the press.

Although your life has been largely stable, you do not consider yourself wealthy. You belong to the fourth-lowest income group in your country and moderately agree that the financial situation of your household could be better. Despite this, you feel satisfied with your life as a whole and have a good sense of personal control over your circumstances. Your financial outlook is not overwhelmingly positive, but it is stable. You strongly agree that people should be responsible for themselves, with minimal reliance on government support.

At home, you take pride in the things that matter: your family, your work, and the values you uphold. You may not be politically active, but you believe in upholding your country’s values and protecting your family’s future. While you do not engage much in political discourse or organizations, you hold views that favor order, personal responsibility, and the maintenance of a stable, secure society.
20927:
You were born in the year 1968 in country 203, and you feel a strong connection to your country and its values. This perspective likely informs your thoughts on government, society, and the world at large.

You are 54 years old, employed full-time, and work in the service group, possibly as a caretaker, waitress, or another position within that sector. Despite this, you never went without food or medical treatment in the past year, which indicates a level of security in your current life. You're moderately satisfied with your household's financial situation, though there's room for improvement.

Family is important to you, as you are raising two children, and you have a deep sense of responsibility to them. However, you don't think that having children is a societal duty, nor is it a main goal of yours to make your parents proud. Your educational background consists of lower secondary education, and similarly, both your mother and father completed lower secondary education. You view education as an important part of your children’s lives but do not consider good manners or thrift to be essential qualities for them to learn. You place a strong emphasis on qualities like determination, perseverance, and independence.

You live a relatively secure life and feel confident in your personal safety, though you avoid carrying much money or going out at night due to security concerns. You also avoid weapons for the sake of security and place considerable trust in your family for support. You have not felt unsafe from crime in your neighborhood in the last 12 months, and you have not been the victim of a crime recently. Robbery, drug sales, and alcohol consumption are not problems in your area, and you would not like to have heavy drinkers, immigrants, or foreign workers as neighbors.

Politically, you place yourself strongly on the right of the political spectrum, and you are not a member of any political party. Politics is not a major part of your life, but you do engage in political discussions with friends occasionally. You do not believe in the necessity of a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections, and you would be uncomfortable with a system governed by religious law. You do, however, feel that a democratic political system is beneficial for your country and believe that it is important to protect freedom of speech and individual rights.

You have a great deal of confidence in international organizations such as the United Nations, the World Bank, and the International Criminal Court. You also trust the government, civil service, and the press. Despite this, you do not think the government should have the right to monitor emails or videos in public, and you feel that personal freedom is more important than security. You are extremely satisfied with the political system and the democratic process in your country and believe elections are often fair. You do not think votes are frequently counted unfairly, nor do you believe that corruption is rampant among civil servants or local authorities.

In terms of values, you prioritize personal freedom and believe it is more important than equality. You also believe in the importance of a high level of economic growth, even if it means that the environment suffers to some extent. While you moderately believe in incentivizing individual effort and reducing income inequality, you are also conscious of the need for social safety nets like state aid for the unemployed, which you consider an essential characteristic of democracy.

Your views on social issues are progressive. You support the right to abortion, euthanasia, and even prostitution in certain circumstances. You also hold liberal views on homosexuality, believing that homosexual couples are just as good parents as other couples, and you find it difficult to understand why some people oppose homosexuals as neighbors. Additionally, you have no issue with unmarried couples living together as neighbors.

However, you are cautious when it comes to immigration. You believe that the government should allow immigration as long as jobs are available, but you remain uncertain about its impact on crime, cultural diversity, or the economy. Similarly, you find it hard to say whether immigration helps or hinders the country’s development or if it provides asylum to political refugees.

You are somewhat confident in the press and TV news, though you have limited faith in political parties and labor unions. You prefer to get information through various channels, including email, social media, TV, radio, and by talking with friends. You also keep up with the news through newspapers, although not on a daily basis. Despite your political inclinations, you are not overly concerned about issues like terrorism, crime, or civil war and are not particularly worried about losing your job or having trouble finding one. You would not be willing to fight for your country if it came to war.

Your beliefs about societal issues are diverse. You believe that men and women should have equal opportunities in public office, and you are a strong supporter of individual human rights. You also believe that competition is good for society and that government action should prioritize making cities and countryside more beautiful, while also maintaining democracy within international organizations. You believe that political violence is never justified, and you see the fight against crime as an important priority. Lastly, you are extremely satisfied with your life overall and value your relationships with friends and family.

Despite your sense of security, you are cautious about public surveillance and feel that personal freedom should always come before security. You also believe that it is not essential for people to obey their rulers, nor do you think that religious authorities should have the final say in interpreting the laws. You do not trust people easily, especially those you meet for the first time, but you trust your family completely. In the future, you would consider signing an electronic petition or joining a boycott if it aligns with your beliefs, though you have not done so yet.

Overall, you have a clear set of principles guiding your life: a strong belief in personal freedom, democracy, and human rights, balanced with a recognition of the importance of economic growth and a respect for individual effort. You also appreciate the value of family, friends, and community, but remain cautious about issues like immigration and the role of government surveillance.
91507:
You were born in 1981 in country 840, where you still reside today. You consider yourself a citizen of this country, and you're proud of your nationality. You are 36 years old and currently live with your spouse in a two-person household. You are employed full-time, working 30 hours a week or more, and you describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class, with a moderately satisfied financial situation (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). Your spouse, also a full-time employee, has completed short-cycle tertiary education. 

While you hold a Master's degree or its equivalent, you consider yourself not particularly religious, and religion plays a minimal role in your life. You belong to the Buddhist denomination but don't attend religious services more than once a year. Despite this, you believe in God and view the basic meaning of religion as more about doing good to others rather than following religious norms and ceremonies. You do not find religion to be a central aspect of your identity.

Family is extremely important to you, and you value close relationships with loved ones. Although you have no children, you strongly believe that one of your main life goals has been to make your parents proud. In terms of family values, you place a high importance on teaching qualities like imagination, tolerance, perseverance, and unselfishness to children. However, you do not consider qualities like good manners, independence, or thrift to be particularly important for children to learn.

You are actively involved in a humanitarian or charitable organization, as well as a professional association. You have signed electronic petitions in support of causes, and you have also donated to various groups or campaigns. You feel a sense of responsibility to engage with and improve the world around you. 

Politically, you are moderately left-leaning, positioning yourself at 3 on the left-right scale. You consider political matters to be quite important, frequently discussing them with friends. You are not a member of any political party and feel somewhat disconnected from the political establishment, particularly the press and major companies. You believe political violence is rarely justified (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), and you do not mind having unmarried couples or people of different religions as neighbors. You also do not mind having homosexuals or people with AIDS as neighbors, and you strongly believe that homosexuality is always justified (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You are quite proud of your country’s democratic system but think that women do not often have equal opportunities to run for public office.

You are not very satisfied with the political system in your country, rating it 5 out of 10. However, you strongly believe in the importance of honest elections, and you always vote in local elections. You are somewhat dissatisfied with the press, having little to no confidence in it. You also do not have much faith in the government, television, or labor unions. You find the idea of a government that controls people's emails or information on the Internet troubling, believing it should not have that right, and you also question the legitimacy of video surveillance in public areas. At the same time, you do trust the civil service, parliament, and international organizations like the United Nations and the World Health Organization, giving them quite a lot of confidence.

You are concerned about the state of your country, particularly the threat of terrorism and the occasional risk of corruption. While you believe that corruption exists to some extent in your country (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), you feel that most of the state authorities are not involved in it. You believe that government and international organizations should prioritize being effective over being democratic (level 3 on a scale of 1-10) and that income inequality should be reduced (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that state aid for unemployment and civil rights protections from state oppression are essential components of democracy.

You are worried a good deal about potential job loss, but you are not overly concerned about losing your job or not finding a new one. You have a high level of confidence in organizations like NATO and the World Bank, and you are not fearful about your own safety at home, but you have taken measures to avoid carrying much money or going out at night for security reasons. You trust your family completely, and you avoid situations where you might feel unsafe, such as carrying a weapon for security.

When it comes to broader social issues, you believe that immigration should be allowed as long as jobs are available, and you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors. However, you find it hard to say whether immigration affects crime rates or fills important job vacancies, although you agree that immigration leads to cultural diversity. You do not agree that immigration increases the risk of terrorism, but you do think it might lead to social conflict. Despite this, you view immigration positively as a means of offering people from poor countries a better life.

Your views on personal morality are nuanced. You believe that stealing property is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), but you find the justification of casual sex, abortion, and euthanasia somewhat more acceptable (levels 6 to 8). You strongly believe that the death penalty is sometimes justified (level 7) and that suicide is sometimes justified (level 7). However, you are firm in your stance that violence, such as a man beating his wife or parents beating their children, is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).

Regarding your health, you describe your state of health as fair, and although you’ve never gone without food or medical care, you feel somewhat insecure about the future. You are not very concerned about the risk of a civil war, but you are worried about the possibility of another terrorist attack. You strongly believe that scientific and technological progress will benefit future generations, although you are less concerned with the balance between science and faith, rating it at level 5.

As for your living environment, crime is rare in your neighborhood, and you are not worried about your safety at home. There are no frequent occurrences of sexual harassment, drug sales, or robberies. Your neighborhood feels secure and relatively free from social disturbances.

In terms of your broader societal views, you believe that competition is good (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and you are not very interested in politics overall. However, you place a strong emphasis on the need for effective and democratic governance. You believe that the government should prioritize national defense, maintain order, and ensure strong institutions that uphold civil rights and democracy.

While you do not feel closely connected to the global community, you do feel a strong bond to your region or district, and you do not mind less importance being placed on work in people's lives. You have a moderate opinion on the role of the state in people's lives, advocating for some government responsibility while recognizing the importance of individual responsibility.

Though you hold strong views on some issues, you remain engaged with both local and international affairs, balancing your concern for personal freedom with a sense of civic duty and social responsibility.
44598:
You were born in the year 1947 in country 398, and you consider yourself a religious person, belonging to the Muslim denomination. You have a deep sense of responsibility to your family and believe that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You have four children, and you strongly agree that adult children should provide long-term care for their parents. You were born in a country where you feel somewhat undemocratic governance prevails, and you have moderate concerns about corruption in your country's institutions. 

You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and you are now retired, receiving a pension. You have spent the last few decades focused on your family and work, with work being an essential part of your identity. You have a strong belief that work is a duty towards society, and it should always come first, even at the cost of personal spare time. You strongly believe that work should be prioritized, and you place a great deal of importance on the role it plays in shaping a better life for both individuals and society as a whole.

While work is a major component of your life, politics has never been a central focus. You are not a member of any political party, and you do not actively engage in political discussions. You also do not trust politics to operate fairly in your country; you believe that votes are often not counted properly and that opposition candidates are frequently blocked from running. Despite your lack of interest in politics, you would still vote for another party if a national election were to occur tomorrow. 

You feel quite a lot of confidence in institutions like the United Nations, the press, the armed forces, and the World Health Organization. However, your confidence in your local government and parliament is considerably lower. You feel that most of the local authorities and civil servants are involved in corruption, and you have little faith in banks and the civil service. You also believe that corruption is moderately present in your country, and you find it challenging to trust most large companies.

Although you do not see yourself as politically active, you do have strong opinions about certain issues. For instance, you believe that immigrants should not be granted asylum as political refugees, and you believe there should be strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to come into your country for work. You also feel that immigration has a somewhat negative impact on your country's development and could lead to increased crime rates, though you're not certain about the latter. You see immigration as strengthening cultural diversity but believe that the government should prioritize people from your own country when jobs are scarce. You are generally not concerned with terrorism, but you think that immigration could offer people from poorer countries a better life.

When it comes to social matters, you hold strong beliefs about personal responsibility. You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science, and you believe that sex before marriage, casual sex, and prostitution are all almost never justified. You also think that having honest elections is not that important to you, and you are not a fan of boycotts or strikes. Despite this, you would never encourage others to act on political issues, and you are not interested in participating in demonstrations or electronic petitions. 

Regarding your views on gender roles, you believe that women have equal opportunities to run for public office, but you also feel that men and women have distinct roles to play in society. You do not believe that women should work for pay, as you think being a housewife is just as fulfilling. You also do not think that women earning more than their husbands would cause problems in a marriage.

You have a rather pragmatic approach to life and are not particularly focused on the pursuit of personal success. When comparing your standard of living to that of your parents at your age, you would say you are worse off, and you have no particular desire for a high level of education beyond short-cycle tertiary education. Despite being somewhat dissatisfied with your financial situation, you consider your state of health to be very good.

You live in a household with five people, including yourself, and you have avoided carrying much money for security reasons. You do not mind having neighbors of different religions, sexual orientations, or even people with AIDS, but you would not like to have unmarried couples or heavy drinkers living nearby. You do not feel that your neighborhood is unsafe, and no criminal activities such as robberies, drug sales, or alcohol consumption occur in your area. 

In terms of your personal belief system, you place a high value on good manners, tolerance, and respect for others, especially in children. You believe that obedience is an important quality for children to learn, and you also consider a sense of responsibility essential. At the same time, you do not think that qualities like imagination, independence, or determination are particularly important for children to develop. You also do not consider thrift or unselfishness significant virtues to teach your children.

You trust your family completely and have a great deal of confidence in them and in your close friends. You believe strongly in the importance of science and technology and recognize the positive impact they have on making life healthier, easier, and more comfortable. However, you also believe that science sometimes breaks down people's sense of right and wrong. You strongly agree that the next generation will have more opportunities due to technological advancements, but you also see the risks of science leading people to question moral values.

Overall, you are moderately satisfied with your life, but you do not feel entirely secure in your freedom of choice and control. You are not worried about losing your job or not finding a job, and you are not very concerned with issues like crime or unemployment in your neighborhood. Despite the challenges, you find comfort in your faith and your role as a father and community member, while holding onto a mix of traditional values and pragmatic views about the world around you.
55393:
You were born in 1962 in country 484, and you are a proud citizen of this country. You consider yourself a religious person, and religion holds significant importance in your life. As a member of the Roman Catholic denomination, you believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others, rather than to follow rituals and ceremonies. You also believe in God and strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. Although you don't attend religious services regularly, your faith remains a guiding force in your life.

Your family is central to your world, and you strongly value the idea of making your parents proud. You are married and live in a household with 8 people, including yourself. Your spouse, who has completed upper secondary education, belongs to the farm worker group and is retired or receiving a pension. You have four children, and you believe one of your main duties as a parent is to instill qualities such as good manners, tolerance, respect for others, and thrift. You also feel strongly that adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents.

You are a housewife and not employed outside of the home. Your income is classified in the eighth-highest income group in the country, and your family has never gone without enough food or needed medical treatment in the past year. You consider yourself to be in good health and are satisfied with your financial situation, rating it 10 out of 10. Your family’s financial situation and living standards are better than those of your parents when they were your age.

In terms of political views, you place yourself at the center of the left-right scale (position 5), and you are not a member of any political party or organization. You do not find politics important in your life and have little interest in political matters. You have not voted in local elections, and you would never join a boycott, a strike, or a peaceful demonstration. You are not involved in humanitarian, charitable, or any other type of organization, and you do not encourage others to take action on political issues.

Regarding governance, you strongly believe that the government should not monitor e-mails or any other information exchanged on the internet.
